revisions.rev:
{{Infobox figure skater |name= Alice Cook |image= |caption= |fullname= Alice Maxine Cook |altname= |country= [[United States]] |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1955|11|30}} |birth_place= [[Lansing, Michigan]] |hometown= |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= {{convert|157|cm|ft|abbr=on}} |partner= |formerpartner= [[William Fauver]] |coach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |formerchoreographer= |skating club= |retired= }} ''' Alice Maxine Cook''' (born November 30, 1955 in [[Lansing, Michigan]]) is an [[United States|American]] [[pair skater]]. With partner [[William Fauver]], she is the 1976 [[United States Figure Skating Championships|U.S. silver medalist]]. They represented the [[United States at the 1976 Winter Olympics]], where they placed 12th.
Following her skating career, Cook became a television sports reporter. She began working for [[WBZ-TV]] in [[Boston, Massachusetts]] in 1984, where she worked until 2010, when her contract was not renewed.[http://bostonherald.com/business/media/view.bg?articleid=1238290] She has reported for [[ESPN]]. She hosted the figure skating coverage for [[Turner Broadcasting System|Turner Sports]] during the [[1998 Winter Olympics]]. She has won the Action for Children's Television award, two Service to Children awards from the NAB, several Parents' Choice Awards for the program "Rap Around,", and the Gracie Award (named for [[Gracie Allen]]), given for excellence in portraying women in a positive light, for a segment on Mari-Rae Sopper, a former gymnast killed in the [[9/11]] incident.
Cook is a Magna Cum Laude graduate of [[Boston College]] where she earned a bachelor of arts degree in history and speech communication.
